bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul L. Tate, March 4, 1953

div1.p: Hench writes that the Cubans asked him to help them determine the relative contributions of the Americans involved in the yellow fever work. He agrees with Tate that Warner has misrepresented her role in the experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul L. Tate, March 4, 1953
div1.opener:
March 4, 1953
Mr. Paul L. Tate
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley 3, California
My dear Mr. Tate:
div1.p:
Thank you very much indeed for your nice letter of February 23. I am glad
to have your honest appraisal of Miss Warner's “reminiscences.” It is
simply amazing how “old soldiers”, as the years pass by, remember things
that never happened. The unfortunate thing is that her remarks did get
published; if not in toto, they were quoted rather extensively by a later
writer.

As to the appearance of her name on the memorial tablet at Camp Lazear which
was dedicated last December, this was strictly the decision of the Cubans.
They asked me to streighten them out on the relative contributions of every
American concerned. At the expense of considerable work I made a more or less
complete list of the names and even the initialed participants with a careful
breakdown as to what each person did. Then the Cuban committee decided which
of the Americans should be mentioned. I too was disturbed that they left off
Captain Stark and Doctor Pinto and when I heard about it I objected to that
but they decided to honor essentially only those who worked at Camp Lazear,
plus of course Lazear himself. They did not even list Dean - “XY” and because
whatever contribution Captain Stark made was simply in line of duty and was
largely, if not entirely, done at the post hospital, he was left out. By this
very definition, Miss Warner should have been left out but they decided to
include Doctor Ames for obvious reasons (and I am delighted they did because,
as you know, he has not been honored as much as he should have been), Lambert
also for obvious reasons and they added Miss Warner chiefly because she ap-
parently nursed Lazear and two or three of the earliest volunteers who developed
experimental yellow fever and I suspect also because the records as to just
which nurses took care of which volunteers is not clear. I think they gave
her credit because they suspected that she may have nursed more of the
volunteers from Camp Lazear than General Truby and others believe she did.

Permit me to send you a copy of a letter which I sent after my return from
Cuba. I hope you will find it of interest.

I am at the moment immorsed in a project which has me hanging on the ropes but
as soon as I finish it (in two or three weeks) I hope to send General Truby
75 or more pictures of the Camp Lazear dedication ceremonies. I should be de-
lighted if, while he has them, you find opportunity to call on him or, if this
is not mutually agreeable (I know that General Truby has not been too well) I
Mr. Paul L. Tate
- 2 -
March 4, 1953
would be quite happy to have him lend you these photographs for a day or
two, remembering that they are merely being sent around to interested per-
sons to find out if they want to order any and the longer they are held up
the longer will be the delay in getting the photographs to the various
interested persons.

I have been asked to describe the dedication of Camp Lazear before the
staff of the Mayo Clinic which I shall do in the next two months. The
description will be published in the Proceedings of the Staff Meetings
of the Mayo Clinic and I will certainly send you a copy.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosure
P.S.: Did I ever send you the article published in “The Pharos” which
told how Moran, Pogolotti and I found Camp Lazear? I think I did but if
not, let me know and I will send you one.
I appreciate greatly your correspondence. Please don't apologize for the
length of your letter. The more, the better. I think you know that the whole
story has been a thrilling one to me and the project continues to occupy
much of my thoughts. The next time I come to California (I expect to at-
tend the meeting of the American Medical Association in San Francisco in
June, 1954) I certainly will want to see you and spend a few hours with
you asking you certain questions and discussing the whole thing.
